At 01:49 17/10/2005, you wrote:
>Hi Ian,
>
>I used a very simple 'accelerating' compatibility threshold in order to
>discover more quickly the correct threshold when large changes are
>required, but it didn't take into account a 'where are we' and 'where do
>we want to be' approach, just a 'too hot'/'too cold' hence I think the
>scheme has a tendency to overshoot sometimes since the acceleration may
>be moving the threshold in large increments if a large change in its
>value has been necessary. So I think I might try and adapt something
>similar to the scheme you describe.
>
>BTW are you still evaluating with Tic-Tac-Toe players?

Yup.  I've not been saying anything, because I'm also upgrading the 
algorithm at the same time, but I have been keeping going with a 
population, even though the algorithm operating on it is still 
regularly upgraded.  Obviously once the algorithm stabilizes I'll 
have to rerun it from the start with a constant environment.

For the moment, my top player has normalised PPS(legal-nl) of 0.9219 
(or 92.19%, which is easier to think about).  There's definitely a 
sharp decrease in rate of progress at around 90% so things are 
getting quite slow now.  That's one of the main reasons I've 
continued to upgrade the algorithm, trying to keep the rate of progress up :)

>I find that more
>simple and hence faster fitness functions are more conducive for testing
>and experimenting with when developing code. Just a thought.

It's a good thought, but in this case I think I need to validate both 
the search method and the definition of PPS, so I'm kinda stuck with 
it.  I have been considering ways of rapidly estimating the PPS, 
instead of iterating through all 627 boards, but I didn't try coding 
anything yet...

>Seems like good progress is being made anyway. Keep it coming!

How are you doing, I hope you are still on it?

         Ian


In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
